titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Sylvia O'Brien Papers AIA.054
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-02-21T14:34-0500

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in 15 record cartons and 1 manuscript box

did.abstract: Sylvia O’Brien (1924-2006) was a Dublin-born, New York-based actress who starred in Broadway theater productions, as well as commercials and television programs. A member of Actor’s Equity Association, the Screen Actors Guild, and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA), O’Brien appeared in numerous Broadway productions, including a role as Mrs. Peace in the 20th anniversary production of My Fair Lady. This collection consists of diaries, playbills, photographs, correspondence, memoranda, newspaper clippings, original writings, and scripts for various performances. The majority of the collection documents her professional career as an actress, including contracts, photographs, correspondence, newspaper clippings, a large collection of playbills, and files on individual productions she participated in. The collection also documents her personal life, including diaries, correspondence, a large number of personal photographs and photograph albums, and her original poetry and short stories.
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu at least two days prior to research visit.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Sylvia O’Brien (1924-2006) was a Dublin-born, New York-based actress who starred in Broadway theater productions, as well as commercials and television programs. O’Brien was born in the Rathmines suburb of Dublin, Ireland in 1924 and emigrated to the United States in 1959 following her involvement with the travelling Irish Festival Singers. In 1959, she married Richard Seadar, the American road manager for the Irish Festival Singers tour. A member of Actor’s Equity Association, the Screen Actors Guild, and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA), O’Brien appeared in numerous Broadway productions, including a role as Mrs. Peace in the 20th anniversary production of My Fair Lady. In addition to her acting career, O’Brien also wrote poetry and short stories, many of which were published in American and Canadian magazines. She died in 2006.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection documents the personal and professional life of Sylvia O’Brien, and consists of diaries, playbills, photographs, correspondence, memoranda, newspaper clippings, original writings, and scripts for various performances. The majority of the collection documents her professional career as an actress, including contracts, photographs, correspondence, newspaper clippings, a large collection of playbills, and files on individual productions she participated in. The collection also documents her personal life, including diaries, correspondence, a large number of personal photographs and photograph albums, and her original poetry and short stories.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Sylvia O’Brien, the creator of this collection, were transferred to New York University in 2010 by Bruce Seadar. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Bruce Seadar, Sylvia O'Brien's husband's nephew and the executor of her estate, in 2010.

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: Upon receipt, the collection contained several distinct types of materials, but no consistent overall arrangement. Similar types of materials (i.e. playbills, scripts) were often grouped together, but not uniformly. The majority of materials were in folders, some of which had accurate titles, but were in no discernable order; other materials were loose and unfoldered. All materials were rehoused in acid-free folders and boxes, grouped into three series, and arranged alphabetically. Original folder titles were used, with descriptive clarifications as necessary, when present. When no original folder title existed, one was supplied by the archivist. Framed photographs were removed from their frames.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA) New York Local Records (WAG 282)

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Approximately 1 linear foot of published books were separated to the library collection for cataloging.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Sylvia O'Brien Papers; AIA 054; box number; folder number;
Archives of Irish America, Tamiment Library
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are organized into three series, all of which are arranged alphabetically:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series documents O’Brien’s professional life as an actress and her interest in the performing arts, beginning with her involvement in the Irish Festival Singers to her later Broadway roles. Major productions include Da, Me and My Girl, and My Fair Lady. Materials include playbills, photographs, correspondence, newspaper clippings, and scripts for various performances.

Productions: How to Survive a Marriage
Productions: The Killing of Sister George

Scripts: Toys in the Attic (Lillian Hellman)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of diaries, correspondence, memoranda, photographs, newspaper clippings, and other materials documenting O’Brien’s personal life and interests. The majority of the series consists of 40 years of her diaries, which she entitled “Sylvia’s Musings.” In her diaries, O’Brien discusses both personal and professional matters, including her daily activities, marriage, friendships, vacations, family history, and social activities; her thoughts of various current events and social issues; and her reflections of professional matters, including auditions, particular aspects of individual productions, as well as interactions with cast members, crew, and theatrical management. The series also includes biographical and genealogical information, scrapbooks, personal photographs, and subject files on issues of interest to O’Brien.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of research notes, drafts, typescripts, and published versions of O'Brien's articles, poetry, and short stories.
